data.title: Famous Birthdays on June 2
data.meta_description: Famous birthdays for the 2nd of June. See which celebrities, historical figures, scientists and criminals were born on June 2.
data.text:
Birthdays 1 - 200 of 221

Murakami, Emperor of Japan (d. 967)

Domenico Ghirlandaio [Bigordi], Italian Renaissance painter, and mentor of Michelangelo, born in Florence (d. 1494) [birthdate disputed]

George van Egmond, Dutch bishop of Utrecht (d. 1560)

Leo XI [Alessandro Ottaviano de' Medici], Italian Pope in 1605 who had the shortest reign as pope in history, born in Florence (d. 1605)

Giovanni Righi, Italian composer and friar, born in Fabriano, Papal States (d. 1539)

Willem Bontekoe, Dutch sailor who published journal of his shipwreck in Indonesia aboard the Nieuw Hoorn, born in Hoorn, Holland (d. 1657)

Benjamin Rogers, English composer (Hymnus Eucharisticus), born in Windsor, England (d. 1698)

Herman-François Delange, Belgian composer, born in Liège, Dutch Republic (d. 1781)

Michel-Jean Sedaine, French dramatist (Le Philosophe sans le savoir), born in Paris (d. 1797)

Marquis de Sade

French philosopher and writer (Justine) and where the words sadism and sadist are derived from, born in Paris, France

Antoni Weinert, Polish composer, born in Lusdorf, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1850)

Cornelis Rudolph Theodorus Krayenhoff, Dutch hydraulic engineer (began Defense Line of Amsterdam), cartographer and soldier, born in Nijmegen, Dutch Republic (d. 1840)

Jan Ekels, the Young, Dutch painter, born in Amsterdam (d. 1793)

John Randolph [of Roanoke], American planter, Congressman (Virginia) and Minister to Russia, born in Cawsons, Virginia (d. 1833)

William Lawson, English born explorer of New South Wales, Australia, born in Finchley, England (d. 1850)

Adrian van der Hoop Jr, Dutch poet and critic (d. 1841)

Isaac Strauss, French violinist, conductor and composer, born in Strasbourg, France (d. 1888)

Robert Führer, Czech composer of sacred music, and music theorist, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1861)

Philip Kearny, American Major General (Union Army), born in New York City (d. 1862)

Ion Brătianu, Romanian statesman (Premier of Romania 1876-88), born in Pitești, Principality of Wallachia (d. 1891)

Gédéon Ouimet, French Canadian politician (d. 1905)

Samuel Wilks, British physician and founding father of clinical science, born in London (d. 1911)

James Cutler Dunn Parker, American organist, composer, and pedagogue, born in Boston, Massachusetts (d. 1916)

Olivier Métra, French composer of ballets, light opera, and popular waltzes (Esperance!), and conductor, born in Reims, France (d. 1889)

Benjamin Hardin Helm, American Brigadier General (Confederates) and Abraham Lincoln's brother-in-law, born in Bardstown, Kentucky (d. 1863)

1831 Jan Gerard Palm, Curaçao bandmaster, choir master, and composer known as as the "Father of Curaçao's classical music", born in Curacao (d. 1899)

Pius X [Giuseppe Sarto], Italian 257th Roman Catholic Pope (1903-14 - lowered age of Communion from 12 to 7,) and saint, born in Riese, Kingdom of Lombardy–Venetia, Austrian Empire (d. 1914)

Grand Duchess Alexandra Petrovna of Russia (née Duchess Alexandra Frederica Wilhelmina of Oldenburg), German-Russian noblewoman and philanthropist, born in St. Petersburg, Russian Empire (d. 1900)

Thomas Hardy, poet and novelist (Far from the Madding Crowd), born in Higher Bockhampton, Dorset (d. 1928)

Arthur MacArthur, Jr, American career military officer (US Army - Civil War, American Indian Wars, Spanish-American War, Philippine–American War), born in Chicopee Falls, Massachusetts (d. 1912)

Paul-Albert Besnard, French painter and graphic artist (La femme), born in Paris, France (d. 1909)

Sophus Tromholt, Norwegian astrophysicist and photographer (photographed Sami people), (d. 1896) [1]

Edward Elgar

English composer (Coronation Ode, Pomp and Circumstance), born in Lower Broadheath, Worcestershire, England

Karl Adolph Gjellerup, poet (Poutnici Svetem, Nobel 1917), born in Roholte, Denmark (d. 1919)

(Paul) Felix Weingartner, Austrian pianist, conductor (Vienna Philharmonic, 1907-27; first to record all nine of Beethoven's symphonies), and composer (Die Dorfschule), born in Zara, Dalmatia, Austria-Hungary (now Zadar, Croatia) (d. 1942)

Ben Webster, British actor (Old Curiosity Shop), born in London, England (d. 1947)

George Lohmann

England cricket medium pace bowler (18 Tests, 112 wickets @ 10.75), born in Kensington, England

Jack O'Connor, American baseball catcher (Cleveland Spiders, St. Louis Browns) and manager (St. Louis Browns), born in St. Louis, Missouri (d. 1937)

John Hope, American educator (President of Atlanta Baptist/Morehouse College,1906-36 and Atlanta University, 1929-36), born in Augusta, Georgia (d. 1936)

Hakon Børresen, Danish composer, born in Copenhagen, Denmark (d. 1954)

Adolf Herckenrath, Flemish playwright and poet (Avondvlam), born in Aaist, Belgium (d. 1958)

Bokke R. S. Pollema, Dutch Frisian journalist, poet, and author (Lok en Lijen (Happiness and Suffering)), born in Makkum, Netherlands (d. 1948)

Howard Johnson, American lyricist ("When the Moon Comes over the Mountain", "M-O-T-H-E-R"), born in Waterbury, Connecticut (d. 1941)

Ernst Kunz, Swiss composer, born in Bern, Switzerland (d. 1980)

1891 Thurman Arnold, American attorney and jurist (d. 1969)

American golfer (first African-American to join PGA Tour, 2 titles), born in Charlotte North Carolina
